instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.SMC_TMS: What is SMC_TMS? SMC_TMS is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SPI_MLB_MOSI: What is SPI_MLB_MOSI? SPI_MLB_MOSI is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..
definitions.SPI_MLB_MISO: What is SPI_MLB_MISO? SPI_MLB_MISO is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
Welcome to my nightmare...

Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that was liquid damaged. After cleaning ultrasonically I replaced the following by looking for any burnt pins/what looked bad to get a fan spin:

Replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> was all over the place) and replaced <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> which was burnt
Replaced <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> which was burnt then <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> as a precaution.
Removed J6100 and cleaned up the pins, main one that was burnt was pin 30 (<SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL>)
There were also some red burn marks on the traces for <SIGNAL>LPC_CLK24M_SMC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> but the traces are OK. Replaced SMC as a precaution.

Now fan spins, I get all main power rails, I get a light on a USB mouse when plugged in but no video/POST. CPU gets warm after a while but not mega hot. Fan spins from normal then up to maximum.

I get 0V on <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MOSI</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SPL_MLB_CLK</SIGNAL>
I get 3.3V on <SIGNAL>SPIROM_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> which comes from <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> which I think means the BIOS is stuck in programming mode from reading about this issue?

Have swapped over <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> - no change.

Any ideas what to check next? So annoying to be close to figuring this hellish board out.

Board readings as follows:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.61 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.418 V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.347 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.15 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 5.15 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.14 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.349 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 3.347 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.345 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3.347 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.342 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> 5.14 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> 3.343 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> 1.356 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> 1.357 V
<SIGNAL>PP0V675_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> 0.674 V
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> 0.68 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> 1.045 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.515 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.041 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> 1.043 V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.745 V

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.384 V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3.414 V
<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> 0 V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 3.346 V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.344 V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 3.345 V

<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL> 3.349 V
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MISO</SIGNAL> 3.341 V
<SIGNAL>SPIROM_WP_L</SIGNAL> 3.347 V
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MOSI</SIGNAL> 0 V
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CLK</SIGNAL> 0 V
<SIGNAL>SPIROM_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> 3.31 V
<SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> 3.31 V

<SIGNAL>LPC_CLK24M_SMC</SIGNAL> 1.704 V


Thanks,

Jon

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
out of curiosity, what do you get on HDMI out or using displayport-vga to boot directly into 3S162 EFI ASD? try booting from a drive that only has 3s162 efi on it. 

<SIGNAL>SPIRPOM_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> means when the signal is [I]low[/I], as in 0v, reset. 3.3v means the signal is not asserted. Are <SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL> and the other 3 signals along that(TDO, TDK) all high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message: If USB mouse lights up even after pulling it out and plugging it in again the board must be alive. Connect external keyboard and do a PRAM reset and see if there is a chime.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 16523"]out of curiosity, what do you get on HDMI out or using displayport-vga to boot directly into 3S162 EFI ASD? try booting from a drive that only has 3s162 efi on it.

<SIGNAL>SPIRPOM_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> means when the signal is [I]low[/I], as in 0v, reset. 3.3v means the signal is not asserted. Are <SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL> and the other 3 signals along that(TDO, TDK) all high?[/QUOTE]

Ah finally an explanation for all those _L signals that makes sense to my idiot brain to understand. Thanks :)

No HDMI output on IO board but USB mouse lights up from there as well. Don't own a displayport-vga unfortunately tried a displayport-dvi but still nothing. When trying to boot from a drive that has only 3S162 EFI I get nothing and no power/activity lights on USB stick I'm trying to boot off. USB mouse lights up fine even after pulling out and plugging in again.

<SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL>, TDO, TDI and TCK all high at 3.4V, although I don't really know what that means.

I read somewhere on the advancedreworks forum that <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> should be 0V or SPI reset is done - is that true or BS as I get 3.3V for that?

Should I be more concerned about missing the following BIOS voltages?

<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MOSI</SIGNAL> 0 V
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CLK</SIGNAL> 0 V

They're all present when BIOS removed and all resistors look good which would indicate to me bad <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>? Have a third replacement on its way just in case

Current skill level = repair monkey. A far better and more accurate description than 'junior member'

Any further ideas before I heatgun my own face out of frustration (gotta heatgun something right?)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message: If mouse lights the board is booting to some degree. Connect a known good LCD and see if there is voltage on L8300.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 16633"] Connect a known good LCD and see if there is voltage on L8300.[/QUOTE]

0V on L8300 with known good LCD.

I plugged a SanDisk Ultra USB3.0 in that has my ASDs on and I get a slow blue pulsing light, the same sort of light as when you used to get the sleep light on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> models before the screen would come on. Don't know if that's relevant but thought I should mention it

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
Following on from that In my very unscientific test I get the same slow blue pulsing SanDisk USB light on a known good MacBook Pro before the chime/screen comes on (after that the light changes to a different 'on' pulse) measuring 0V on L8300 and have no output on HDMI or displayport so I'm guessing it's stuck in that state before video output/chime where it could be 100 different things causing it? :(

I noticed that <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> measures 1.05V, 1.04V or 1.03V depending where I measure on the board. I'm guessing this isn't normal!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message: Where did you take the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> from? Put back the original one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 16732"]Where did you take the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> from? Put back the original one.[/QUOTE]

Tried 3 different <CHIP>U6100S</CHIP>: 1 x original, 1 x from dead board from aliexpress, 1 x from dodgy eBay unlock people. Same symptoms on all of them.

I replaced the SMC again with another one off a donor board: CHIME! Backlight and video output fine :D I figured something weird must be going on between the communication of the SMC/BIOS and I've gone through 3 BIOS chips already so...

Thanks for the help really appreciated! Something else to add to my monkey check list if I get this problem again. Monkey is getting smarter thanks to Duke and Louis!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message: Will post voltage readings later now it's working and what behavior has changed in comparison for reference if anyone else is having this problem in future. But you can mark this as solved for now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL> high. NO POST
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 16785"]Put back original <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>![/QUOTE]

Put back original <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> after I got it to boot with the 2nd SMC replacement. Thanks for the help - everything seems fine now and ASD doesn't flag up anything to be concerned about. Job done :)
